titleproper.value: Guide to the Carpenters for a Stronger Union Records <num>WAG.066</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2019-07-24T14:04:13</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

unittitle.value: Carpenters for a Stronger Union Records

extent.value: in 2 record cartons and 1 manuscript box.

abstract.value: In 1981, a small group of individuals acted in concert to organize and agitate within the District Council of Carpenters in New York City and some of its twenty-two locals in an effort to dislodge their corrupt leaders. Calling themselves Carpenters for a Stronger Union (CSU), they publicly challenged their elected officials. The records of the Carpenters for a Stronger Union include election materials, newsletters, flyers, NLRB decisions, correspondence, typescripts and newspaper clippings.

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Carpenters for a Stronger Union Records; WAG 066; box number; folder number or item identifier; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

The papers were created and collected by Frank McMurray and Michael Murphy while members of the New York City District Council of Carpenters, and of their respective local unions; McMurray in Local 608, the "Irish" local, and Murphy in Bronx Local 488, which later became part of Local 17. The first set of records were donated by Frank McMurray in 1988, prior to his move to California. Michael Murphy donated his papers in the summer of 1994. The accession number associated with these gifts is 1988.008. Two audiocassette tapes were donated by Jane LaTour in December 2018. The accession number associated with this gift is 2019.034.

<list><item>Attie, Jeanie, and Steinberg, Allen. <title render="italic">Carpenters - New York State: A History of the New York State Council of the Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, 1881-1981</title>. Buffalo: New York State Council of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, 1982.</item><item>Brooks, Thomas. <title render="italic">Road to Dignity: A Century of Conflict: A History of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, AFL-CIO, 1881-1981</title>. New York: Atheneum, 1981.</item><item>Christie, Robert A. <title render="italic">Empire in Wood: A History of the Carpenter's Union</title>. Ithaca New York: Cornell University Press.</item><item>Corruption and Racketeering in the New York City Construction Industry. <title render="italic">Interim Report by the New York State Organized Crime Task Force</title>. Ithaca NY: ILR Press, Cornell University, 1988.</item><item>Galenson, Walter. <title render="italic">The United Brotherhood of Carpenters: the First Hundred Years</title>. Cambridge: Harvard University Press, 1983.</item><item>Horowitz, Morris A. <title render="italic">The Structure and Government of the Carpenters' Union</title>. New York: Wiley, 1962.</item><item>Hutchinson, John. <title render="italic">The Imperfect Union: A History of Corruption in American Trade Unions</title>. New York: E.P. Dutton, 1970.</item><item>Lyon, David Nicholas. <title render="italic">The World of P.J. McGuire: A Study of the American Labor Movement, 1870-1890</title>.</item><item>Raddock, Maxwell C. <title render="italic">Portrait of an American Labor Leader: William L. Hutcheson: Saga of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, 1881-1954</title>. New York: American Institute of Social Science, 1955.</item><item>Schneirov, Richard, and Suhrbur, Thomas J. <title render="italic">Union Brotherhood: Union Town: The History of the Carpenters, 1863-1987</title>. Chicago: University of Chicago, 1988.</item><item>Seidman, Harold. <title render="italic">Labor Czars: A History of Labor Racketeering</title>. New York: Liveright, 1938.</item></list>
Prominent names appearing in the records are Ted Maritas, Paschal McGuinness, John O'Connor, Martin Forde, Benny Schepis; Arthur Giangrande; Sammy "the Bull" Gravano.

Labor union democracy -- New York (State) -- New York.
Labor unions -- Corrupt practices -- New York (State) -- New York.
